body:
@AudriusButkevicius 
That is great news! I'm very happy to see this enhancement.

So Windows seems to be the show stopper here, as first of all you cannot create links via standard go APIs, and even if you do create them somehow else, reading where the symlink points to is close to impossible.
So I can now read and create symlinks, but creating them requires administrator privileges

I hope you won't make Dropbox's [mistake](https://forums.dropbox.com/topic.php?id=80823). The main reason I switched from Dropbox is that it converts symlinks to normal files. Please leave POSIX symlinks as is.

@sergey-vlasov What if the symlink target doesn't exist on one of my syncthing remotes? In this case the dropbox behaviour, of converting symlinks to normal files, is desirable. The only case where I wanted to sync the plain symlink would be if it's target is in the same syncthing folder.

@KLINGTdotNET In that case there should be an option whether to convert symlinks, leave as is, or ignore (current behavior). Forcing to new behavior now is going to break many user's file trees, including mine.

@AudriusButkevicius When you place a symlink `~/Dropbox/mydir -> /some/other/dir` to Dropbox, it copies all the content from `/some/other/dir/*` to their cloud. So on all other nodes `~/Dropbox/mydir` won't be a symlink anymore but a regular directory with all subdirectories and files, copied from the source.

@KLINGTdotNET: Why? Syncthing syncs file. It shouldn't care about it's content. It should not analyze them and alter them based on arbitrary conditions. It should just replicate the directory just like copy-pasting would do (but two-way, and keeping the newest version). If your data refers to data external to your repository that's _your_ desicion.

@AudriusButkevicius: Which means that if I used dropbox, **both my directories trees would be different**. I don't want two different trees: I'm using a syncronization tool! Not only that, but their size could differ massively.

That would also result in other supercomplicated scenarios.
- What do you sync if the symlink is broken?
- What do you sync if you don't have read access to the destination.
- What do you sync if the destination is a non-regular and non-directory file.
- What do you do if the symlink is a directory with more symlinks?
- What do you do if the symlink is a directory with recursive (or infinite) loops?

Finally, when syncing directory trees, it's _very_ common to use symlinks when we want to _avoid_ recurring into part of the tree and syncing it (eg: syncing ~/.config, and having ~/.config/syncthing be a symlink to somewhere else).

Meanwhile, there's no evidence that altering the file tree and copying the destination's content could be of any use under any scenario. No use-case has been provided of when that may be useful.

Well that is not what we are (or rather I am) aiming for.
I literally intend to do symlink -> symlink transfers, regardless of whether the link is valid or not, with perhaps slash conversions, but that's about it.

It will obviously won't work if you have absolute paths (unless the layout is the same), but should work for relative paths even cross Windows and Linux, the only caveat is that we'll need admin privileges on Windows which I haven't solved yet. 
I guess we could fail to create the symlinks and warn the user, but then I am left to work out how to achieve 'in sync' state and stop repeatedly transferring it.

I guess we could mitigate the problem by embedding a manifest into the binary, but since the builds are produced on Linux, I don't think the relevant utilities exist.

The other thing I haven't worked out is how to distinguish between a directory symlink and file symlink on Linux, as they seem to be the same thing, where on Windows they are different things.
Especially when the target doesn't exist...

So any input on the issues above would be useful.
